Thanks for the catch, label is the label index of the multi-class to be predicted. Would you like to open a PR to fix this? We can add the line of document of label to here

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/softmax_output.cc#L24

Then it will be automatically reflected. Thanks!

http://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/contribute.html#git-workflow-howtos

This require change to the graph executor by adding something like rebind the input shape. This is possible, but require a bit engineering effort, including check the allocated memory and run re-allocation if the size is too small
@tqchen sorry about the rebase issue, this is the first time meet such thing. thx for help. but I find I make it wrong

@FBracun This should be fixed in #1044 

Now you can do what you want. Since the symbol is a `S4` object, `slice_gates[[1]]` is preferred.

Just tell me if you really want something like `slice_gates[1]`.

```
require(mxnet)

indata = mx.symbol.Variable("data_")

LSTMParam <- setRefClass("LSTMParam", fields = c("i2h_weight", "i2h_bias", "h2h_weight", "h2h_bias"))

LSTMState <- setRefClass("LSTMState", fields = c("c", "h"))

prev_state <- LSTMState$new(c = mx.symbol.Variable("init_c"),
              h = mx.symbol.Variable("init_h"))

param <- LSTMParam$new(i2h_weight = mx.symbol.Variable("i2h_weight"), 
              i2h_bias = mx.symbol.Variable("i2h_bias"),
              h2h_weight = mx.symbol.Variable("h2h_weight"),
              h2h_bias = mx.symbol.Variable("h2h_bias"))

num_hidden <- 10

i2h <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = indata,
                                weight = param$i2h_weight,
                                bias = param$i2h_bias,
                                num_hidden = num_hidden * 4,
                                name = "i2h")

h2h <- mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data = prev_state$h,
                                weight = param$h2h_weight,
                                bias = param$h2h_bias,
                                num_hidden = num_hidden * 4,
                                name = "h2h")

gates = i2h + h2h

slice_gates = mx.symbol.SliceChannel(gates, num_outputs = 4, name = "slice")

slice_gates[[1]]
```
Please verify the results on cifar first.

Hmm, that's strange.
How did you install openblas? I know openblas can be compiled without support for this I am not sure if the default binaries disable this as I always build from source. Openblas also has environment variables to enable multiple flags: OPENBLAS_NUM_THREADS. Have a look at https://github.com/xianyi/OpenBLAS.

A quick test that I always do to test blas (assuming you have built numpy to use openblas) is to dot product large random matrices together in a while true. and check cpu usage. This will only help only help debug if numpy is linked against openblas.
did you set EXTRA_OPERATORS? gpu_global_mem what is this?
Can anyone help me with this? The limited help documentation appears to be the biggest obstacle for mxnet to have wider acceptance.
what is EXTRA_OPERATORS? The error is caused when it try to create a directory without root access.

I have never seen this situation if follow the guide https://mxnet.readthedocs.org/en/latest/build.html 
The makefile do create a `build` folder, but is in current path.

You are right, the build is created in the current path. But since I can not run
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install -y build-essential git libatlas-base-dev libopencv-dev
this might be why I have this weird issue.

@tqchen I will send a single PR with changes when I finish working on my model, so that I don't spam you with small changes.

I will also use this issue to ask other questions on documentation if you don't mind (I will rename it correspondingly).

Question:

In the docs for the `Embedding` layer, `input_dim` and `output_dim` seem to mean the shape of the corresponding dimentions, while in the `Concat` layer a parameter `dim` seems to mean the ordinal of the dimension. I assume it is too late to rename the arguments, but at least the docs can be more specific, because in both cases they explain parameter as "dimension". Can you confirm that my understanding is correct so that I can update the docs for `Embedding` layer to make it explicit that those parameters are sizes of the dimensions, not ordinals?

@junshui We are working to improve documents and provide more examples. I will really appreciated your understanding of the situation that we are all students and have limited time.

For usage of `mx.simple.bind()`, you can find a good example from

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/R/model.R#L472

For the documentation, my advice is to use python doc as a reference, like 

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/symbol.py#L495-L499
it looks like launch.py is failed to read `hosts`
Thanks!

you probably need "git submodule update".
@tqchen @antinucleon we get people stumbling on this every now and then. Is there a permanent solution?

@antinucleon I it's probably due the EXTRA_OPERATORS feature I added a week ago. https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/Makefile#L101 It looks like his EXTRA_OPERATORS is NONE but some how passed the if
should be fixed once https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1048 is merged. For now, you can fix it by adding `EXTRA_OPERATORS = NONE` to the end of your config.mk
Thanks, that fix the problem

I've pulled all the modules, I'm on mobile so I can't  share the commit hash for each module. I've used  the solution here to pull from each submodule  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1030169/easy-way-pull-latest-of-all-submodules

Are all if them in master branch?
do you see the line `DMLC_REGISTER_DATA_PARSER(uint32_t, csv, data::CreateCSVParser<uint32_t>);` at the end of dmlc-core/src/data.cc?
Emâ€¦ What can I do?
One of my copy of MXNet on my computer has similar problem. I deleted the folder, clone again and compile, then this problem disappeared.
The problem is make clean did not cleanup the libdmlc.a, so you will need to manually type make clean in dmlc subfolder

thankï¼ŒI set  OPENBLAS_NUMï¼Œbut i find openblas threads is not up to 4ï¼Œeven though i make OPENBLAS_NUM >4. In this case,I rerun mxnet,the speed is faster than before with Speed: 554.65 samples/sec,while it is Speed: 410.65 samples/sec before.  It is worth noting average cpu is lower than 25%. 
However,mxnet is still a lot slower than caffe in the same machine. caffe only need 6mins training mnist,while mxnet need 40 mins.

BTW,before I change openblas environment variables mxnet cost 50min for training mnist and caffe cost 8 min.
Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-4790 CPU @ 3.60GHz, 8core.
mem:16G
I'm sure the team of mxnet has done detailed testing compared to caffe. I believe there is something wrong or abnormal with my situation.Is there someone that give me some instruction?

Does input has so significant impact? The only difference is that caffe uses lmdb as input.
Many thanks for your help. After some research, I saw a lot of potential in mxnet. I have decided to switch to it. Hopefully, you guys can keep it up, and make it one of the dominate DL packages.

I doubt that input has a significant impact. The rec loader in mxnet is very fast. I am able to train the GPU example at crazy fast samples/sec so its probably not that.

As for performance, that is quite strange and I am out of ideas. I just ran the example on my cpu and I am able to get 35k ish samples/second with out touching anything on a less good cpu and get 99% accuracy in 18 seconds. (where as on a 980 i finish in 11 seconds at >100k samples a second).

This leads me to think that it is your setup but I am not sure how or what could be causing this. Sorry. Maybe one of the developers of the project has better ideas.

Don't know if this matters, but I built my openblas and numpy from source.

What does your config.mk look like?
Relevant: #1031

Thank you for your support. We want to make `mxnet` one of the first choices when people want to use deep learning in R.

Right now I am closing this. Feel free to open it if necessary.

your host file has a empty line
delete it and try again
@mli the empty line of host file cause this issue , I have take a PR to ps-lite

please make sure the line https://github.com/tornadomeet/mxnet/blob/seg/example/fcn-xs/image_segmentaion.py#L31 is your correct gpu id; 
you can print information before and end of that line , to see whether it is broken there.
@tornadomeet It broken at the line https://github.com/tornadomeet/mxnet/blob/seg/example/fcn-xs/image_segmentaion.py#L46. And the L31 gets gpu(0), since I have only one GPU, gpu(0) is the correct id.
i cannot reproduce the error here, from what your description, we can get that it broken when loadding the model, so which model do u use, your own trained model or the model i provided?
@tornadomeet I use the model you provided.

@qiaohaijun You are right! Thank you~
@mli Thank you!
@wsybupt you are welcome! go on!

I don't think input has that key role. After all, lmdb is only to be used as input for once only. I run the example directly. For mxnet, i directly run "python lenet.py" without change anything. Following is my
config.mk and lenet.py;
#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Template configuration for compiling mxnet

#

# If you want to change the configuration, please use the following

# steps. Assume you are on the root directory of mxnet. First copy the this

# file so that any local changes will be ignored by git

#

# $ cp make/config.mk .

#

# Next modify the according entries, and then compile by

#

# $ make

#

# or build in parallel with 8 threads

#

# $ make -j8

#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

#---------------------

# choice of compiler

#--------------------

export CC = gcc
export CXX = g++
export NVCC = nvcc

# whether compile with debug

DEBUG = 0

# the additional link flags you want to add

ADD_LDFLAGS =-L/opt/OpenBLAS/lib

# the additional compile flags you want to add

ADD_CFLAGS =-I/opt/OpenBLAS/include

#---------------------------------------------

# matrix computation libraries for CPU/GPU

#---------------------------------------------

# whether use CUDA during compile

USE_CUDA = 0

# add the path to CUDA libary to link and compile flag

# if you have already add them to enviroment variable, leave it as NONE

# USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda

USE_CUDA_PATH = NONE

# whether use CUDNN R3 library

USE_CUDNN = 0

# whether use opencv during compilation

# you can disable it, however, you will not able to use

# imbin iterator

USE_OPENCV = 1

# use openmp for parallelization

USE_OPENMP = 1

# choose the version of blas you want to use

# can be: mkl, blas, atlas, openblas

USE_STATIC_MKL = NONE
USE_BLAS = openblas

# add path to intel libary, you may need it for MKL, if you did not add the path

# to enviroment variable

USE_INTEL_PATH = NONE

# If use MKL, choose static link automaticly to allow python wrapper

ifeq ($(USE_BLAS), mkl)
    USE_STATIC_MKL = 1
endif

#----------------------------

# distributed computing

#----------------------------

# whether or not to enable mullti-machine supporting

USE_DIST_KVSTORE = 1 

# whether or not allow to read and write HDFS directly. If yes, then hadoop is

# required

USE_HDFS = 0

# path to libjvm.so. required if USE_HDFS=1

LIBJVM=$(JAVA_HOME)/jre/lib/amd64/server

# whether or not allow to read and write AWS S3 directly. If yes, then

# libcurl4-openssl-dev is required, it can be installed on Ubuntu by

# sudo apt-get install -y libcurl4-openssl-dev

USE_S3 = 0

lenet.py

# pylint: skip-file

from data import mnist_iterator
import mxnet as mx
import logging

## define lenet

# input

data = mx.symbol.Variable('data')

# first conv

conv1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data, kernel=(5,5), num_filter=20)
tanh1 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=conv1, act_type="tanh")
pool1 = mx.symbol.Pooling(data=tanh1, pool_type="max",
                          kernel=(2,2), stride=(2,2))

# second conv

conv2 = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=pool1, kernel=(5,5), num_filter=50)
tanh2 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=conv2, act_type="tanh")
pool2 = mx.symbol.Pooling(data=tanh2, pool_type="max",
                          kernel=(2,2), stride=(2,2))

# first fullc

flatten = mx.symbol.Flatten(data=pool2)
fc1 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=flatten, num_hidden=500)
tanh3 = mx.symbol.Activation(data=fc1, act_type="tanh")

# second fullc

fc2 = mx.symbol.FullyConnected(data=tanh3, num_hidden=10)

# loss

lenet = mx.symbol.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc2, name='softmax')

## data

train, val = mnist_iterator(batch_size=100, input_shape=(1,28,28))

## train

logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

# dev = [mx.gpu(i) for i in range(2)]

#dev = mx.gpu()
dev = mx.cpu()
model = mx.model.FeedForward(
    ctx = dev, symbol = lenet, num_epoch = 20,
    learning_rate = 0.05, momentum = 0.9, wd = 0.00001)
model.fit(X=train, eval_data=val,
          batch_end_callback=mx.callback.Speedometer(100))
@wsybupt if the problem is fixed, please close this issue.
Compared to original file, I change config.mk use USE_DIST_KVSTORE = 1 ;
If your input is not binary file, you can check out your disk IO load status when training.
can you find the location of the file "nvrtc.h" ?
No. I am not able to do so.. apparently it is not in cuda6.5. is there any macro to disable RTC

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/Makefile#L117

and the code is 
src/common/mxrtc.cc
@mli  does mxnet support cuda 6.5?
maybe you should upgrade your cuda
@qiaohaijun Nothing is related to the Makefile. @piiswrong should have better solution

io wait 0,so io is not the bottleneck.
Although caffe use lmdb, it still uses for once only. Cafee is much a lot faster  than mxnet. The main reason is that mxnet cannot make the most of cpu.

I set OPENBLAS_NUM > 4ï¼Œbut i find openblas threads is actually not up to 4ï¼Œeven though i make OPENBLAS_NUM >4. I use numpy to test and the result is that only 4 cpu cores is up to 100%. If I can make all the cpu up to 100%, mxnet probably can be faster. 
But correspondingly, caffe which use the same openblas in the same machine can also be faster. The speed gap between caffe and mxnet is still significant.

I didn't write the code but you can verify by either 1) check the gradient with gradient checker in test/python/unittests/check_utils.py or 2) compare it with CuDNNBatchNorm
@antinucleon
Thanks for letting us know. I will check CPU version performance. Most time we only pay attention to GPU speed so maybe there is some bug.

Thanks piiswrong, always in time. Sorry I could not test it mysefl now. But honestly, I think it is pretty obvious, just ask related people to check about it. Anyway, It's clearly more of carelessness than a math mistake. 

Note that, in the Inception-BN example, the corresponding m in BN is quit large and the difference can be rather minor as to affect the results. So maybe no one noticed it.
should be fixed after https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1048 is merged
[["mean_img"]] - > ["mean_img"]
@antinucleon nevermind, I went through code, it supports both fully-connected and conv layers, good job. Please see if you will fix issue#1053.

@tqchen I vote for independent repo for java binding. The integrated R package is already making travis test very slow. If we put more language binding and tests into the main repo integration tests is going to take forever.

As a remotely related comment: I think most of the front-end languages have very high quality and robust 3rd party libraries to load many existing data file formats -- at least efficient sequential loading. It might be good to build a generic interface with some supporting modules such that whenever the user has a way to do sequential loading, it could be immediately turn into a dataiter with prefetching, block-wise random shuffling, preprocessing, etc.

before we implemented what caffe's alexnet required, you can
1. either train an alexnet, go examples/image-classification, `python train-imagenet --network alexnet ...`. it only takes several hours on 4 gpus.
2. or use vgg16/vgg19. we verified the results. e.g. `tools/caffe_converter/run.sh vgg16`
